qas.question: What type of climate did Gondwana have during the Cambrian period?
In what hemisphere did west Antarctica share during the Cambrian?
Where was east Antarctica during the Cambrian period?
What was the climate of Gondwana at the beginning of the Devonian period?
Where was Gondwana located by the end of the Devonian period?
What part of Antarctica is currently in the Northern Hemispher?
What was deposited in Western Antarctica while it was in the Southern Hemisphere
What life florishes in East Antarctica's tropical seas?
What dominated the land during the Devion period?
When did Antarctica develop a hot dry climate?
What had a mild climate during the Devonian period?
During the Devonian period, where was East Antarctica?
What type of plants dominated the Devonian period?

context: During the Cambrian period, <b10_0>Gondwana<b10_0/> had a <a0_0>mild<a0_0/> climate. <b5_0>West Antarctica<b5_0/> was partially in the <a1_0>Northern<a1_0/> Hemisphere, and during this period large amounts of <b6_0>sandstones, limestones and shales<b6_0/> were deposited. East Antarctica was <b12_0>at the <a2_0>equator<b12_0/><a2_0/>, where sea floor <b7_0>invertebrates and trilobites<b7_0/> flourished in the tropical seas. By the start of the <b11_0>Devonian period<b11_0/> (416 Ma), Gondwana was in more southern latitudes and the climate was <a3_0>cooler<a3_0/>, though fossils of land plants are known from this time. Sand and silts were laid down in what is now the Ellsworth, Horlick and Pensacola Mountains. <b13_0>Glaciation<b13_0/> began at the end of the Devonian period (360 Ma), as Gondwana became centered on the <a4_0>South Pole<a4_0/> and the climate cooled, though flora remained. During the Permian period, the land became dominated by <b8_0><b14_0>seed plants<b14_0/><b8_0/> such as Glossopteris, a pteridosperm which grew in swamps. Over time these swamps became deposits of coal in the Transantarctic Mountains. Towards the <b9_0>end of the Permian period<b9_0/>, continued warming led to a dry, hot climate over much of Gondwana.
